objdescid.compdate: c. 1785The date is based on stylistic considerations.

provenance.name: Fitzwilliam Museum
provenance.note: Probably inherited by Blake's wife Catherine at his death in 1827; acquired by Frederick Tatham, probably at Catherine Blake's death in 1831; possibly the dealer Joseph Hogarth, sold from his stock, Southgate and Barrett auction, London, 7-30 June 1854, lot 5082, with 21 other works by Blake, on the twelfth evening (16s. to "Edsall," probably a dealer); Richard Johnson; sold from Johnson's collection, Platt's auction, London, 25 April 1912, lot 702 with 16 other works (£11.11s. to Archibald G. B. Russell); sold Sotheby's, 28 May 1934, lot 171 with another pencil drawing (wrongly?) attributed to Blake (£5.10s. to Geoffrey Keynes); bequeathed by Keynes in 1982 to the Fitzwilliam Museum and accessioned by the Fitzwilliam in 1985.

desc.objtitle: Macbeth and the Ghost of Banquo, object 1 (Butlin 154 recto)

objnote.p: Inscribed in pencil "71" or "7/", bottom right, not be Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In this drawing, six figures sit in chairs around a table and one figure stands in the foreground. Facing forward yet looking right, the standing figure has curly hair and perhaps a beard. He bends both arms upward with palms facing forward and fingers spread widely. His stance is wide, and he appears to look directly toward the seated figure at far right, who returns his gaze facing left. This figure, also male, has short curly hair and extends both arms so his hands rest on his bent knees. Detailing near the figure's chest may indicate some decoration on his clothing, though this is unclear. To the left of this figure, the second figure from the right sits behind a table facing forward and looking down. He has short curly hair and perhaps a beard. To the left of this figure, a fourth figure is seen from behind facing away from the viewer and seated on some kind of backless chair or bench. This figure appears to have long hair. His arms appear bent at the elbows and he may cross his right leg behind his extended left. Across the table, a fifth head (with indistinguishable facial features) and torso is visible and may face forward. At far left, the sixth figure is a gowned female who sits facing right. She appears to wear her long hair in a coiffure and rest at least her bent right arm on the table. At least four vertical forms are visible behind the figures and may suggest columns or pilasters or perhaps wall paneling. This drawing may illustrate a scene from Macbeth in which Macbeth (standing) encounters in horror the Ghost of Banquo (seated far right) while at dinner with Lady Macbeth (seated far left) and others.

component.illusobjdesc: In this drawing, six figures sit in chairs around a table and one figure stands in the foreground. Facing forward yet looking right, the standing figure has curly hair and perhaps a beard. He bends both arms upward with palms facing forward and fingers spread widely. His stance is wide, and he appears to look directly toward the seated figure at far right. This figure may be Macbeth who is seeing the Ghost of Banquo in horror.

In this drawing, six figures sit in chairs around a table and one figure stands in the foreground. The figure at far right, who is male, has short curly hair and sits in a reclining posture. He extends both arms so his hands rest on his bent knees. Detailing near the figure's chest may indicate some decoration on his clothing, though this is unclear. He may be the Ghost of Banquo, recognized by Macbeth in horror. There may be some resemblance between the profile of this figure and Blake's own.

In this drawing, six figures sit in chairs around a table and one figure stands in the foreground. The second figure from the right sits behind the table facing forward and looking down. He has short curly hair and perhaps a beard. His mouth may be open, and his left arm may be bent at the elbow with left hand resting on the table.

In this drawing, six figures sit in chairs around a table and one figure stands in the foreground. To the right of this figure, a fourth figure is seen from behind facing away from the viewer and seated on some kind of backless chair or bench. This figure appears to have long hair. His arms appear bent at the elbows and he may cross his right leg behind his extended left.

In this drawing, five figures sit in chairs around a table and one figure stands in the foreground. The third figure from the left, a fifth head (with indistinguishable facial features) and torso is visible and may face forward.

In this drawing, six figures sit in chairs around a table and one figure stands in the foreground. At far left, the sixth figure is a gowned female who sits facing right. She appears to wear her long hair in a coiffure and rest at least her bent right arm on the table. This figure may be Lady Macbeth watching as her husband recognizes the Ghost of Banquo.
In this drawing, six figures sit around a table. At least three—the figures far left and right and the figure third from right—sit on chairs or possibly stools.
At least four vertical forms are visible behind the figures and may suggests columns or pilasters or perhaps wall paneling.
